description: From Middle English pacient, from Middle French patient, from Old French pacient, from Latin patiens, present participle of patior (“to suffer, endure”), from Proto-Indo-European *peh₁- (“to hate, hurt”).

adjectives.description: patient (comparative patienter or more patient, superlative patientest or most patient)

entries.meaning: (of a person) Willing to wait if necessary; not losing one's temper while waiting.
examples: Be patient: your friends will arrive in a few hours.

entries.meaning: Constant in pursuit or exertion; persevering; calmly diligent.
(obsolete) Physically able to suffer or bear.
examples: To this outward structure was joined that strength of constitution, patient of severest toil and hardship; insomuch that for the most part of his life, in the fiercest extremity of cold, he took no other advantage of a fire, than at the greatest distance that he could, to look upon it.

entries.meaning: A person or animal who receives treatment from a doctor or other medically educated person.
(linguistics, grammar) The noun or noun phrase that is semantically on the receiving end of a verb's action.
examples: The subject of a passive verb is usually a patient.

entries.meaning: One who, or that which, is passively affected; a passive recipient.
examples: Malice is a passion so impetuous and precipitate, that it often involves the agent and the patient.
